title: Uranus will appear in the sky tonight and here's where and when you can watch it LIVE
text:
Uranus will make its closest approach to Earth tonight, rising in the East as the sun goes down.
It's the only planet to be discovered by an amateur astronomer, so it's only right that the public gets to have a look at this stunning blue and green planet.
Luckily, the website Slooh is streaming a live view through one of its telescopes starting at about 11pm British time (6pm EDT).
Video loading
"Much remains unknown about this distant ice giant," a Slooh spokesman said.
"It will rise in the east in the constellation Pisces as the Sun sets.
"This marks the closest approach of this blue-green world to Earth this year, and Slooh will broadcast a live show to celebrate the event."
Uranus in the round: These Hubble Telescope images show Uranus rotating
The planet was first spotted by William Herschel on March 13, 1781, using a homemade telescope.
But Uranus remained shrouded in mystery for two more centuries after this initial discovery because of its vast distance from Earth.
"Astronomers later found that Uranus is tilted 98 degrees from perpendicular, which suggests something big may have knocked the planet on its side in its early days," the spokeman added.
"In 1977, Earthbound observers discovered a set of thin, dark rings around the planet.
"And in 1986, the Voyager 2 spacecraft flew just 50,000 miles above the cloud tops of Uranus and imaged the planet close up, discovered 10 more moons, found more detail in the faint rings, and measured a strong magnetic field." PA The white spots in this image of Uranus with white spots show an extremely large storm
Last year, scientists were excited by extreme storms raging on the normally bland surface of the ice giant planet.
The cloud activity is so bright that even amateur astronomers have seen signs of it in the blue-green atmosphere of the planet, which is 30 times further away from the Sun than the Earth.
